A Message to the Carnegie Endowment Community

  • William J. Burns

Wed Jun 03 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

The murder of George Floyd has underscored the deep inequities that have long plagued American society. In a note to the Carnegie community, Bill Burns reflects on Carnegie’s commitment to build a more just future here at home and around the world, without which peace will remain beyond our grasp.

Global Pandemic: Coronavirus and Global Disorder

regularly updated collection

Mon Mar 16 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

As the deadly coronavirus disrupts daily life around the world, Carnegie experts offer analysis on the political, economic, and geostrategic effects of the global pandemic.

The United States and the New World Disorder: Retreat From Primacy

  • Aaron David Miller
  • , Richard Sokolsky

commentary

Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

The coronavirus pandemic has brought the era of highly ambitious U.S. diplomacy to an unceremonious end. As U.S. power wanes, is Washington ready for a world that has never needed it more and trusted it less?

Topics Discussed
  • United States
  • Foreign Policy

  • On the PandemicWilliam J. Burns explains how the coronavirus presents a make-or-break moment for U.S. diplomacy
  • On the United StatesWilliam J. Burns discusses the need for a rebirth of U.S. public service

U.S. Foreign Policy for the Middle Class: Perspectives From Nebraska

  • Salman Ahmed
  • , Allison Gelman, eds.

report

Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

As millions of Americans contend with lost wages and savings due to the coronavirus, the challenge of making U.S. foreign policy work harder for the middle class is even more vital.

Topics Discussed
  • United States
  • Foreign Policy

  • On Colorado The task force looks at how U.S. foreign policy impacts people in Colorado
  • On Ohio The task force looks at how U.S. foreign policy impacts people in Ohio

Contentious Politics in the Syrian Conflict: Opposition, Representation, and Resistance

  • Maha Yahya

Compendium

Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

The Assad regime’s instinct to survive at any cost closed off opportunities for change in Syria, yet contentious politics was possible and is still taking place.

Topics Discussed
  • Syria
  • Arab Politics

  • On SyriaExperts discuss the reason behind the leadership tensions inside Syria | عربي
  • On the Syrian MilitaryMuhsen Al Mustafa explains how Syria’s military has been affected by sectarianism | عربي

Could the Pandemic Jump-Start National Reconciliation in Palestine?

  • Zaha Hassan
  • , Nathan J. Brown

article

Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

Palestinian grassroots organizations are leading the response to the coronavirus pandemic. Many factors will weigh on this new activism’s longevity.

Topics Discussed
  • Palestine
  • Global Pandemic

  • On Palestine Zaha Hassan and Hallaamal Keir write that it is up to Israel to stop a coronavirus catastrophe among Palestinians
  • On U.S. Policy Zaha Hassan and Hallaamal Keir examine U.S. policy responses to the coronavirus in Gaza

South Asia’s Battle With the Coronavirus

  • Rhea Menon
  • , Srinath Raghavan

compendium

Wed May 20 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

In South Asia, the coronavirus pandemic is at once a public health crisis, an economic crisis, and a humanitarian crisis.

Topics Discussed
  • India
  • Coronavirus Pandemic in India

  • Webinar Experts discuss the coronavirus and the future of Indian foreign policy
  • On India Gautam I. Menon examines India’s unheeded coronavirus warning

Global Protest Tracker

interactive

Tue Mar 31 2020 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (EDT)

A one-stop source for following crucial trends in the most significant antigovernment protests worldwide since 2017.

Topics Discussed
  • Democracy, Conflict, and Governance
  • Civil Society

America Needs a Rebirth of Public Service

  • William J. Burns

Atlantic

Sun Feb 23 2020 19:00:00 GMT-0500 (EST)

If ever there were a moment to call Americans to serve, it’s now. To help ensure they answer that call, it’s time to end the war on government, revive U.S. institutions, and shape a new era of public service.

Topics Discussed
  • Americas
  • United States
  • Foreign Policy
  • Economy

  • On the United States George Perkovich critiques the state department’s nuclear posture clarification
  • On Foreign Policy Dan Baer explains why the political campaigns must go on, even during a pandemic

Can the Coronavirus Heal Polarization?

  • Rachel Kleinfeld
  • , Ashley Quarcoo

article

Thu Jan 30 2020 19:00:00 GMT-0500 (EST)

Polarization is straining democracies around the world, but effective governance and mobilization during the crisis could help narrow social divides.

Topics Discussed
  • Democracy and Governance
  • Political Reform

  • On Democracy and Governance William J. Burns explains why America needs a rebirth of public service
  • On Political Reform Marc Pierini looks into Turkey’s looming Gordian knot

Is It a Nuke?: Pre-Launch Ambiguity and Inadvertent Escalation

  • James M. Acton

Thu Jan 30 2020 19:00:00 GMT-0500 (EST)

It’s becoming increasingly difficult to distinguish a nuclear weapon from a conventional one. The risk of misidentifying either—especially prior to its launch—is an underappreciated and growing danger. At a time of geopolitical uncertainty, this confusion could spark a nuclear war.

Topics Discussed
  • Americas
  • Russia
  • Foreign Policy
  • Nuclear Weapons

  • On Nuclear Weapons Ulrich Kuhn discusses nuclear risk in the Euro-Atlantic
  • On Foreign Policy David Whineray details how Trump’s actions allowed China to gain huge global influence
